docs.lead_paragraph: The most comprehensive surveys of medical facilities and maternal deaths ever conducted in Afghanistan show that the country's 25 million people have among the world's worst health and greatest needs, according to Afghan officials and foreign health experts. Particularly hard hit by Afghanistan's 23 years of war, civil strife and Taliban misrule are Afghan women, who are experiencing what health officials call ''catastrophic'' death rates associated with pregnancy and childbirth -- the world's worst, doctors believe.

headline.main: Women Suffer Most in Afghan Health Crisis, Experts Say

docs.abstract: Afghan officials and foreign health experts say that most comprehensive surveys of medical facilities and maternal deaths ever conducted in Afghanistan show that country's 25 million people have among world's worst health and greatest needs; particularly hard hit by Afghanistan's 23 years of war, civil strife and Taliban misrule are Afghan women, who are experiencing what health officials call 'catastrophic' death rates associated with pregnancy and childbirth--world's worst, doctors believe; many Afghans in most remote rural areas have never seen doctor, nurse or paramedic; conditions described; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The most comprehensive surveys of medical facilities and maternal deaths ever conducted in Afghanistan show that the country's 25 million people have among the world's worst health and greatest needs, according to Afghan officials and foreign health...

byline.original: By JUDITH MILLER and CARLOTTA GALL

docs.abstract: Christopher Solomon reviews book Roofwalker by Susan Power (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Britain's universities are often as not in the news, cast either as pinnacles of elitism or swamps of mediocrity. But today they were offered a new, libertine reputation as testing grounds of hedonism -- all thanks to a German condom maker that is offering to pay British students $150 per semester to rate its wares for ease of use and pleasure. In the name of health and commerce, the trials are designed to discover why ''people don't like using them'' at a time when sexually transmitted diseases are spreading quickly, said Victoria Wells, marketing manager in Britain for the German company Condomi. Not coincidentally, the Cologne-based company is also trying to improve its share of the market. It currently claims 10 to 15 percent of the 160 million condoms sold in England each year and ranks as the third biggest supplier.
docs.abstract: Condomi, German condom maker, offers to pay British college students $150 per semester to rate its wares for ease of use and pleasure; is presenting trials in name of health; it is also trying to improve its share of market (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A judge has lifted an order that would have required Planned Parenthood to provide pregnancy test records that the authorities had hoped would lead them to the mother of a dead baby boy. Prosecutors asked the judge, Frank B. Nelson of State District Court, last week to vacate the order to release the tests because they feared an endless court battle.

headline.main: Court Guards Results Of Pregnancy Tests

docs.abstract: Judge Frank B Nelson vacates order that would have required Planned Parenthood's Storm Lake, Iowa, clinic to provide pregnancy test records authorities hoped would lead them to mother of dead baby boy whose body was found at recycling center in May; acts at request of prosecutors, who feared endless court battle (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Mifepristone, once called RU-486, is best known as the abortion pill. But some scientists believe that the drug may eventually serve another, far less controversial, purpose: treating a particularly fierce and intractable form of depression.

headline.main: Abortion Pill May Help Treat Severe Form of Depression

docs.abstract: Corcept Therapeutics psychiatrist and chief executive Dr Joseph Belankoff, in article published in journal Biological Psychiatry, reports finding that mifepristone, abortion pill once called RU-486, is effective in helping people with severe depression accompanied by delusional beliefs or hallucinations; company applies to Food and Drug Administration for approval to market drug for psychotic depression; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Mifepristone, once called RU-486, is best known as the abortion pill.    But some scientists believe that the drug may eventually serve another, far less controversial, purpose: treating a particularly fierce and intractable form of depression.
